title: Slothful coworker demands employee's bonus claiming that she deserves it more, gets 3-week suspension: '[She] is going around the office calling me “selfish” and “greedy”'
description: Hanlon's razor is one of my favorite adages for maintaining sanity in this crazy world, and if you've read a few of these posts, you've probably seen it mentioned almost as many times. The philosophical razor states that one should "Never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity." This is all well and good and helps one to let go of the atrocious and selfish behaviors they witness from others while out and about in the world: they don't mean to be that way they're just—well, dumb… I'd postulate, though, that there is a point where the two qualities of "stupidity" and "malicious intent" intersect—where qualities of significant incompetence become a point of cruelty and malevolence.This idea fits nicely in the case of this coworker who didn't excel in the areas of motivation or personal accountability, instead making her problems those of others with a complete lack of self-awareness.
author: Brad Dickson

This employee secured a bonus for their performance from his employer, which he had worked tirelessly for over the last period. Meanwhile, his coworker had been wasting much of her time on their phone, turning in her work late, and just generally being a deadweight in the office. When the coworker learned the employee had received a bonus for his work, she began demanding that she share part of it with him, going on and on about how she deserved it more.

Now, this is obviously outrageous, and while it would be one thing if this coworker had also been working her “behind” off and, for some reason, was snubbed by management for her fair share of the rewards, even then, it would be a matter of securing her own bonus payout from the employer and not parting off pieces of her coworkers'. 

The employee returned with an update, sharing how he had gone to HR to lodge a complaint, earning his coworker a three-week suspension since she had seemingly been on thin ice already. 

See below the original thread that the employee shared with this online community, followed by the update thread from item #24 onwards.
